Codebook.definition: Software quality encompasses both the development process and the final product.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions both process and product in relation to quality
Discusses how process improvements influence product quality
exclusion_criteria: Only discusses process or product without linking the two to quality
typical_examples: Software quality is both outcome and process.
atypical_examples: Quality takes place at three levels: product, software code, and development process.
Codebook.relevance_to_RQ: This code captures the dual nature of how practitioners define software quality, recognizing the importance of both the development process and the product outcome.
Codebook.notes: Capture the dual aspect of quality in both process and product.

Codebook.definition: Focus on the quality of the code and design, including maintainability and scalability.
exclusion_criteria: Only mentions external quality or user satisfaction
typical_examples: Internal quality has to do with how the software is constructed or built.
We aim for clean code and sustainability of the design.
atypical_examples: It is important to also assure internal quality.
Codebook.relevance_to_RQ: Highlights the dimensions of software quality related to the technical aspects of development, specifically code quality and design.
Codebook.notes: Internal aspects are vital for agile processes that require frequent changes.

Codebook.definition: External quality is defined by a product being free of defects and meeting user needs.
exclusion_criteria: Focuses only on the process or internal quality aspects
typical_examples: The product quality is a functioning product free of defects and conforms with the business needs.
Codebook.relevance_to_RQ: Emphasizes the user-centric aspect of software quality measurements in agile development.
Codebook.notes: Commonly viewed as a main priority for ensuring software meets client expectations.

Codebook.definition: Ongoing evaluation and enhancement of the process to improve quality.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions retrospectives, review, or continuous processes improvements
exclusion_criteria: Discusses quality without mention of iterative improvement
typical_examples: The process is always subject to improvements.
atypical_examples: We learn from our mistakes and improve. It's a journey!
Codebook.relevance_to_RQ: Illustrates the adaptive strategy in Agile methodologies to keep enhancing quality standards.
Codebook.notes: Retrospective practices foster ongoing process enhancements.

Codebook.definition: Quality is enhanced through team collaboration and shared responsibility.
exclusion_criteria: Only discusses individual roles or responsibilities
typical_examples: Collaboration helps better quality by facilitating intensive exchange of information and feedback.
atypical_examples: In agile, everyone is accountable for everything they implement.
Codebook.relevance_to_RQ: Reveals the social dynamics in Agile that influence quality through engagement and collaborative effort.
Codebook.notes: Accountability drives quality through trust and transparency within teams.

Codebook.definition: Certain Agile practices and tools support maintaining and improving quality.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions specific Agile practices or tools such as Scrum, TDD, etc.
Accounts for specific roles like QA in Agile context
exclusion_criteria: Omits role of Agile practices or tools in quality
typical_examples: Agile calls for TDD to support iterative development.
atypical_examples: QA practices are embedded in Agile through Scrum task planning.
Codebook.relevance_to_RQ: Shows how specific practices within Agile frameworks contribute to ensuring software quality.
Codebook.notes: Supports efficacy of Agile with specific methodologies aiding quality control.

Codebook.definition: Quality aligns with managing business expectations and needs iteration.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions aligning developments with user/business expectations
Highlights the role of feedback in managing expectations
exclusion_criteria: Focuses solely on technical or process details without business alignment
typical_examples: You can see quality when business needs are met.
atypical_examples: Quality management involves clear expectation settings in Agile.
Codebook.relevance_to_RQ: Signifies the relationship between Agile processes and how business expectations are mediated for quality outcomes.
Codebook.notes: Expectation management is essential in refining user stories and iterations for quality delivery.
